over_extrusion_statements.statement: Over-extrusion occurs when a 3D printer's nozzle delivers more filament than required, resulting in excessive material deposition, bulging layers, and poor print quality.

The most common causes of over-extrusion include incorrect extrusion multiplier settings, excessive nozzle temperature, and poor filament calibration, which can result in thicker walls, warping, and reduced dimensional accuracy.

High extrusion multiplier settings in the slicer can lead to over-extrusion by instructing the printer to extrude more material than needed, causing excess material oozing and inconsistent layer stacking.
Excessive nozzle temperature can cause over-extrusion by making the filament too fluid, leading to uncontrolled material flow, droopy features, and a loss of fine print details.
Incorrect filament diameter settings in the slicer can result in over-extrusion if the actual filament diameter is smaller than the entered value, causing uneven surfaces and thick, bulky prints.
Poor filament quality or inconsistent diameter can lead to over-extrusion, producing messy print surfaces and poor overall part aesthetics.
Over-extrusion often results in visible blobs or strings of excess material, which can ruin the print's surface finish and fine details.
When over-extrusion occurs, layers may appear uneven or overly thick, leading to poor layer adhesion and structural weaknesses.
Excess material from over-extrusion can cause dimensional inaccuracies, making printed parts fail to fit properly in assemblies.
Over-extrusion can lead to increased internal stress in parts, causing them to warp or deform after cooling.
A clogged nozzle or partial blockage can sometimes simulate over-extrusion, causing irregular blobs and poor consistency in layers.
Over-extrusion increases print times and material usage unnecessarily, reducing the efficiency of the printing process.
In extreme cases, over-extrusion can cause nozzle collisions with excess material, leading to skipped steps or failed prints.
Thick over-extruded layers can reduce the sharpness of corners and edges, resulting in rounded or imprecise geometries.
Over-extrusion can create weak inter-layer bonding by forming overly thick layers that do not adhere properly to one another.
Excessive filament flow can obscure intricate details, making prints look sloppy or poorly defined.
Over-extrusion often produces a glossy or uneven surface finish, reducing the visual appeal of the printed object.
When over-extrusion occurs, infill areas may become overly dense, leading to excessive weight and wasted filament.
Over-extrusion can cause bridging failures as sagging or excess material accumulates in unsupported areas.
Addressing over-extrusion requires careful adjustment of slicer settings, nozzle temperature, and filament calibration to restore accurate and consistent material flow.
